description: The Forbidden City is an imperial palace complex in central Beijing, China. It served as the home of Chinese emperors and the ceremonial and political center of the Chinese government for almost 500 years.

The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications built to protect Chinese states against nomadic groups. The Beijing section includes Badaling and Mutianyu, which are among the best-preserved parts.
The Summer Palace is a vast ensemble of lakes, gardens, and palaces. It was an imperial garden in the Qing Dynasty, now serving as a popular tourist destination and recreational park.
The Temple of Heaven is an imperial complex of religious buildings. It was visited by Emperors of the Ming and Qing dynasties for annual ceremonies of prayer to Heaven for good harvests.
The 798 Art District is a thriving art community housed in decommissioned military factory buildings, showcasing contemporary art and cultural events in a unique industrial setting.
The Bund is a waterfront area in central Shanghai, featuring a spectacular display of international architecture styles. It's one of the most recognizable symbols of Shanghai.
The Oriental Pearl Tower is a distinctive landmark in Shanghai's Pudong district. This TV tower features observation decks offering panoramic views of the city.
Yu Garden is an extensive traditional garden located beside the City God Temple in Shanghai. This classical garden from the Ming Dynasty combines various architectural styles.
Nanjing Road is the main shopping street in Shanghai and one of the world's busiest shopping districts, offering everything from traditional Chinese goods to luxury brands.
Shanghai Disneyland is a theme park located in Pudong, featuring unique attractions and experiences tailored for Chinese visitors while maintaining Disney's magical atmosphere.
The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor.
Xi'an's Ancient City Wall is one of the oldest and best-preserved city walls in China. Built during the Ming Dynasty, it forms a complete enclosure around the old city.
The Big Wild Goose Pagoda is a Buddhist pagoda built in 652 during the Tang Dynasty. It was built to store the sutras and Buddha figures that Xuanzang brought back from India.
The Muslim Quarter is a historical neighborhood featuring Islamic culture and cuisine. It's known for its vibrant street food scene and cultural heritage of the Hui people.
Mount Hua is one of China's Five Great Mountains, known for its steep cliffs and treacherous paths. It offers breathtaking views and has significant religious importance.
Jinli Ancient Street is one of the oldest commercial streets in Sichuan. It features traditional architecture, local snacks, and folk handicrafts, offering a glimpse into the region's cultural past.
Wuhou Temple is dedicated to Zhuge Liang, a famous strategist during the Three Kingdoms period. The temple contains numerous historical relics and beautiful gardens.

The Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding is a non-profit research and breeding facility for giant pandas, featuring naturalistic habitats where visitors can observe pandas in a setting resembling their natural environment.
Wide and Narrow Alleys consists of three parallel ancient city alleys restored to reflect traditional Sichuan architecture. It's now a popular area with shops, restaurants, and teahouses.
Mount Qingcheng is one of the most important centers of Taoism in China. Known for its peaceful atmosphere, ancient temples, and lush greenery, it's a UNESCO World Heritage site.
West Lake is a freshwater lake in Hangzhou, famous for its scenic beauty that has inspired poets and artists for centuries. It's surrounded by gardens, pagodas, and historical relics.
Lingyin Temple is one of the oldest and most significant Buddhist temples in China. Located in a forested area, it features remarkable Buddha sculptures carved into the hillside.
Songcheng Park is a theme park showcasing the culture of the Song Dynasty. It features historical performances including the famous show 'Romance of the Song Dynasty'.
Longjing Tea Fields are where China's famous Dragon Well tea is grown. Visitors can tour the plantations, learn about tea production, and participate in tea ceremonies.
The Grand Canal is the world's longest artificial waterway, connecting Hangzhou to Beijing. The Hangzhou section offers boat tours showcasing historical sites and traditional lifestyles.
Shamian Island is a sandbank island with a rich colonial history, featuring European-style mansions and tree-lined avenues that create a unique cultural enclave in Guangzhou.
Canton Tower, also known as Guangzhou Tower, is a TV and observation tower offering spectacular views of the city. It's known for its distinctive hourglass design.
Chen Clan Ancestral Hall is a traditional Chinese academic temple and clan temple complex, showcasing remarkable Cantonese architecture, decorative arts, and folk crafts.
Baiyun Mountain offers panoramic views of Guangzhou from its peaks. Known as the 'City's Lung', it provides a natural escape with hiking trails, gardens, and cultural sites.
Shangxiajiu Pedestrian Street is a bustling commercial area with hundreds of shops housed in traditional Cantonese architecture, famous for retail shopping and local cuisine.
Hongyadong is a stilt house complex built along the steep cliffs of Jialing River. This commercial pedestrian street recreates traditional Chongqing architecture on multiple levels.
Jiefangbei is the central business district of Chongqing, featuring a large pedestrian square with a Liberation Monument at its center, surrounded by shopping malls and skyscrapers.
The Yangtze River Cableway offers a thrilling aerial crossing of the Yangtze River, providing spectacular views of the city's mountainous terrain and river confluence.
Ciqikou Ancient Town is a restored trading port from the Ming and Qing dynasties, featuring traditional architecture, teahouses, artisan shops, and street food vendors.
Wulong Karst is a UNESCO World Heritage site featuring dramatic limestone formations, including the Three Natural Bridges, Furong Cave, and Houping Tiankeng sinkhole.
Central Street is a pedestrian street featuring European-style architecture, reflecting Harbin's Russian influence. It offers shopping, dining, and historical buildings.
Ice and Snow World is the main venue of the Harbin International Ice and Snow Sculpture Festival, featuring massive illuminated ice buildings and sculptures.
Saint Sophia Cathedral is a former Russian Orthodox church built in 1907, now serving as a museum. Its distinctive Byzantine architecture makes it a symbol of Harbin.
Sun Island is a scenic area across the Songhua River, known for its beautiful gardens in summer and snow sculpture exhibitions in winter.
Harbin Polar Land is one of the largest indoor polar themed parks in the world, featuring polar animal exhibits, performances, and interactive experiences.
The Potala Palace is a symbol of Tibet, formerly the winter residence of the Dalai Lamas. This UNESCO World Heritage site stands on Marpo Ri hill, dominating the Lhasa valley.
Jokhang Temple is the spiritual heart of Tibet, housing important Buddhist relics. The surrounding Barkhor Street is a sacred circumambulation route and bustling market.
Sera Monastery is one of Tibet's great Gelugpa monasteries, famous for its debating monks who use dramatic gestures as part of their Buddhist philosophical debates.
Namtso Lake is one of the highest saltwater lakes in the world and considered one of the most beautiful places in Tibet, with crystal clear waters against a backdrop of snow-capped mountains.
Yaowang Mountain offers panoramic views of Lhasa and surrounding mountains. It features prayer flags, stupas, and is a popular spot for capturing photos of the Potala Palace.
Gulangyu Island is a pedestrian-only island off Xiamen, known for its colonial architecture, piano culture, and vehicle-free environment, earning it UNESCO World Heritage status.
Zhongshan Road is a historic commercial street in Xiamen, featuring a mix of traditional and modern architecture, shopping opportunities, and local Minnan cuisine.
Nanputuo Temple is a famous Buddhist temple dating back to the Tang Dynasty, beautifully situated between the sea and mountains, featuring classic Chinese temple architecture.
Island Ring Road is a scenic coastal highway circling Xiamen Island, offering beautiful sea views, beaches, and recreational facilities along its 31-kilometer stretch.
Hulishan Fortress is a late Qing Dynasty coastal defense structure featuring ancient cannon emplacements, military exhibits, and panoramic views of the Taiwan Strait.
Ancient Culture Street is a lively Qing-style pedestrian street filled with folk-craft shops, temples, and traditional Tianjin snacks, offering a deep dive into local heritage.
Italian Style Town preserves dozens of early-20th-century European villas along the Haihe River, creating a romantic neighborhood of cafés, galleries, and boutiques.
Built over the Haihe River, the 120-meter-tall Tianjin Eye Ferris wheel provides sweeping 360-degree views of the city’s old concessions and modern skyline.
The Five Great Avenues district showcases more than 2,000 well-kept Western-style buildings from the 1920sC30s, reflecting Tianjin’s cosmopolitan past.
An evening cruise along the Haihe River lights up historic bridges, renovated warehouses, and illuminated skyscrapers for a picturesque city panorama.
Once the Qing emperors’ summer retreat, this vast UNESCO site blends imperial palaces, lakes, and hillside temples amid beautiful natural scenery.
Founded in 586 AD, Longxing Temple in Zhengding is famed for its 21-meter bronze Avalokitesvara statue and richly carved wooden pagodas.
Known as the ‘First Pass Under Heaven’, Shanhai Pass is where the Great Wall meets the sea, featuring formidable Ming-era fortifications.
Baiyangdian is North China’s largest freshwater wetland; reed marshes, lotus ponds, and lake villages are explored by wooden boats.
Yesanpo offers karst gorges, clear rivers, and verdant mountains, ideal for rafting, hiking, and appreciating dramatic canyon landscapes.
A perfectly preserved Ming-Qing walled town with cobbled lanes, courtyard residences, and China’s earliest draft bank―now a UNESCO site.
More than 51,000 Buddhist statues carved into sandstone cliffs in the 5th century, illustrating early Chinese Buddhist art.
Built into a sheer cliff 75 m above ground, this 1,500-year-old wooden monastery uniquely combines Buddhist, Taoist, and Confucian elements.
One of China’s Four Sacred Buddhist Mountains, featuring ancient temples scattered across five flat-topped peaks.
An opulent 18th-century merchant mansion famed for its maze-like courtyards and intricate brick-and-wood carvings.
Endless green steppe dotted with yurts, herds, and rivers―one of China’s most pristine grassland ecosystems.
Vast pastures known for Naadam festivals, horse racing, and authentic nomadic culture.
A monumental complex honoring the Mongol conqueror, combining memorial halls, cultural exhibitions, and traditional rituals.
A desert playground where singing dunes ‘whistle’ underfoot, offering camel rides, sandboarding, and starry-night camping.
Towering dunes up to 500 m high conceal sapphire lakes, creating surreal desert-oasis scenery fit for off-road exploration.
The former Qing dynasty palace predating Beijing’s Forbidden City, containing ornate halls and priceless Manchu relics.
Dalian’s coastal park combines aquariums, coral halls, and cliffside boardwalks overlooking the Bohai Sea.
Asia’s longest underground navigable river winds through spectacular stalactite chambers lit by colorful lights.
Granite peaks, ancient pine trees, and cliff-hugging temples earn Qianshan the nickname ‘Northeast Huangshan’.
A historic railway bridge bombed during the Korean War; visitors walk to mid-river for views of North Korea across the Yalu.
A volcanic crater lake at 2,189 m above sea level, famed for azure waters and snow-capped ridges.
China’s largest man-made forest and lake park, ideal for rowing, cycling, and winter skiing.
A scenic reservoir surrounded by forested hills, offering boating in summer and ice fishing in winter.
Frost-covered willows create fairytale ‘rime’ scenery each January along the Songhua River.
Experience traditional Korean architecture, dance, and cuisine in China’s largest Korean autonomous prefecture.
Nanjing’s lantern-lit riverfront blends Ming-era temples, arch bridges, and bustling snack streets.
Suzhou’s largest classical garden, recognized by UNESCO for its ponds, pavilions, and poetic landscapes.
A 88-meter bronze Buddha near Wuxi alongside an ornate Brahma Palace and Nine-Dragon Bathing show.
Yangzhou’s ribbon-like lake dotted with arched bridges, islands, and pavilions romanticized by poets.
A riverside temple in Zhenjiang famous for the ‘Legend of White Snake’ and panoramic views from its pagoda.
Granite peaks, twisted pines, seas of cloud, and hot springs make this UNESCO mountain range a Chinese landscape icon.
A lakeside Huizhou-style village with moon-shaped ponds and stone bridges, beloved by photographers.
Another classic Huizhou merchant village; its exquisite ancestral halls and carved wood facades date back to the 16th century.
One of China’s four sacred Buddhist mountains, dotted with temples and steep pilgrimage trails.
Marble peaks and deep gorges form dramatic scenery once praised by ancient poets.
Mist-shrouded peaks, waterfalls, and early 20th-century villas earned Lushan a UNESCO World Heritage listing.
Known as the ‘cradle of the Chinese revolution’, it offers red-history sites amid verdant forests.
Interactive exhibits and live firing demonstrate the 1,000-year porcelain heritage of Jingdezhen.
Granite spires and Taoist temples rise above seas of cloud, creating ethereal vistas.
Rebuilt many times since 653 AD, this iconic pavilion on the Gan River symbolizes Nanchang’s cultural legacy.
Mount Tai is one of China's Five Great Mountains and a UNESCO site, revered since ancient times for its sunrise views and historic stone inscriptions.
Laoshan rises directly from the Yellow Sea near Qingdao, famed for granite peaks, Taoist temples, and coastal hiking trails.
In Qufu, the vast temple-mansion-cemetery complex honors Confucius, preserving 2,000 years of worship and classical architecture.
Qingdao’s iconic pier stretches into the sea beside red-roofed German architecture, offering postcard views of the city’s skyline.
Fed by artesian springs, Jinan’s Daming Lake features willow-lined causeways, pavilions, and reflections celebrated in classical poetry.
Birthplace of Chan (Zen) Buddhism and Shaolin kung fu, this 1,500-year-old monastery sits amid forested Mount Song.
100,000 Buddhist statues carved into limestone cliffs along the Yi River form a UNESCO masterpiece of Chinese stone art.
A living recreation of Song-dynasty Kaifeng with performances, wooden ships, and folk marketplaces.
Sheer red-sandstone gorges, emerald pools, and the 314 m Yuntai Waterfall draw hikers year-round.
The last capital of the Shang dynasty preserves royal tombs and oracle bones―earliest Chinese written records.
Wuhan’s riverside tower, rebuilt many times since AD 223, is immortalized in Tang poetry and offers sweeping Yangtze views.
UNESCO complex of Taoist temples and palaces nestled among misty peaks―also the cradle of Wudang martial arts.
The world’s largest hydroelectric project spans the Yangtze, with visitor platforms overlooking massive ship locks.
Primeval forests harbor golden snub-nosed monkeys, alpine meadows, and legends of the ‘wild man’ Yeren.
China’s largest urban lake covers six scenic areas of cherry blossoms, bamboo groves, and cycling paths in Wuhan.
Sandstone pillars shrouded in mist inspired the floating mountains of *Avatar*; glass bridges and cableways reveal dizzying vistas.
Changsha’s leafy peak hosts ancient Yuelu Academy, Lushan Temple, and autumn maple scenery.
Stilted wooden houses line the Tuo River in this well-preserved Miao minority town of alleyways and lanterns.
A long sandbar mid-Xiang River famous for Mao Zedong’s youthful poem and seasonal orange groves.
One of China’s five sacred peaks; pilgrims climb 7,200 stone steps past temples to the South Heavenly Gate.
Karst peaks mirrored in jade waters between Guilin and Yangshuo create China’s most celebrated landscape painting come alive.
A 1,400-year-old lane of cafés, boutiques, and nightlife blending backpacker culture with rural scenery.
Asia’s largest transnational waterfall thunders on the ChinaCVietnam border amid lush subtropical forest.
Fine quartz-sand stretches 24 km along the Beibu Gulf, famed for gentle waves and spectacular sunsets.
Centuries-old Zhuang and Yao terraced paddies curve over steep mountainsides, shining like dragon scales.
Sanya’s crescent-shaped beach offers crystal water, coral reefs, and luxury resorts―dubbed ‘Oriental Hawaii’.
Granite boulders inscribed with ‘Edge of the Sky, Rim of the Sea’ mark China’s romantic southernmost landmark.
A snorkeling paradise with colorful reefs and white sand just off Sanya’s coast.
Dense jungle, cascading rivers, and rare flora form China’s first tropical rainforest national park.
A 108 m seaside Guanyin statue, temples, and vegetarian cuisine celebrate Buddhist culture near Sanya.
One of Asia’s biggest waterfalls plunges 77 m over a 101 m cliff, with a walk-behind water curtain cave.
China’s largest Miao settlement illuminates tiered wooden houses and singing-dance rituals.
UNESCO Biosphere Reserve with mushroom-shaped peaks and cliff-edge temples above sea-of-clouds vistas.
Red sandstone cliffs, bamboo forests, and 4,000 waterfalls form a stunning Danxia landform corridor.
A 12 km karst cave system showcases giant stalagmite halls nicknamed ‘Underground Palace of the Gods’.
Cobbled lanes, Naxi courtyards, and water canals create a UNESCO World Heritage mountain town.
A turquoise high-plateau lake ringed by cycling paths, white-walled villages, and snow-capped peaks.
Glacier-tipped massif near Lijiang, accessible by cable car to 4,500 m and famed for meadow wildflowers.
Towering limestone spires form a labyrinthine ‘forest’, a highlight of karst geology.
One of the world’s deepest canyons where the Jinsha River roars between 3,000 m cliffs―classic multi-day trek.
492 cave temples near Dunhuang safeguard 45,000 m2 of Buddhist murals spanning a millennium.
‘Rainbow Mountains’ display multicolored stratified sandstone ridges sculpted by wind and water.
A crescent-shaped oasis amid towering dunes; camel treks and dune-sledding at sunset are popular.
The western terminus of the Ming Great Wall stands guard over desert silk-road routes.
Buddhist grottoes carved into red cliffs, reached by ladders and offering prairie views of the Qilian Mountains.
China’s largest saltwater lake glows turquoise each summer, surrounded by cycling routes and fields of yellow rapeseed.
Mirror-like salt flats reflect cobalt skies―dubbed the ‘Mirror of the Sky in China’.
Birthplace of Tsongkhapa, founder of the Gelug school, famed for yak-butter sculptures and golden rooftops.
High-altitude pass on the ancient Silk Road, offering stark alpine vistas and prayer-flag-strewn slopes.
Source region of the Yangtze, Yellow, and Mekong Rivers protects snow leopards, Tibetan antelope, and vast plateau wetlands.
Sand Lake blends desert dunes with a vast freshwater lake, offering bird-watching, reed boating, and dramatic yellow-sand scenery.
Thousands of prehistoric petroglyphs depicting hunting and totems are etched into Helan Mountain’s cliffs, telling stories of nomadic tribes.
Part of the Tengger Desert meets the Yellow River here―ride camels, slide down singing dunes, or walk the famous sheepskin raft.
Eleven pyramid-shaped royal mausoleums and over 200 satellite tombs preserve the mysterious legacy of the 11th-century Western Xia dynasty.
Yinchuan’s restored Ming-era gate tower and city wall give panoramic views over the old quarter and evening market bustle.
A sapphire alpine lake at 1,980 m, ringed by snow-clad Tianshan peaks and spruce forests―legendary home of a Western Queen.
Deep-blue glacial lake in Altai Mountains famed for misty coves, Siberian taiga, and mythical ‘lake monster’ tales.
Labyrinthine mud-brick alleys, centuries-old mosques, and bustling Sunday Bazaar showcase Silk Road Uyghur culture.
China’s largest desert offers endless golden dunes, desert highways, and night skies ablaze with stars.
Iron-red sandstone ridges near Turpan appear to burn under the sun―setting of the classic novel *Journey to the West*.
Once the world’s tallest skyscraper, the bamboo-shaped tower provides sweeping city views and hosts a world-class New Year’s fireworks show.
Marble cliffs, turquoise rivers, and tunnel-hewn roads create Taiwan’s most dramatic national park landscape.
Taiwan’s largest alpine lake mirrors forested hills; cycle paths and Thao aboriginal culture ring its jade-green waters.
Mist-filled cedar forests, sunrise ‘sea of clouds’, and the vintage forest railway epitomize Taiwan’s mountain charm.
Tropical beaches, coral reefs, and lighthouse-topped capes make Kenting a watersport and sunset hotspot on Taiwan’s southern tip.
Ride the Peak Tram to Hong Kong’s highest vantage for postcard harbor skylines, hiking paths, and dusk city lights.
Since 1888 the green-and-white ferries shuttle between Hong Kong Island and Kowloon, offering iconic harbor vistas for pennies.
A 34-m bronze Buddha sits atop Ngong Ping Plateau on Lantau Island, reached by scenic cable-car ride.
After dark, bargain stalls, fortune-tellers, and street-food steam mix into Kowloon’s liveliest open-air bazaar.
Classic Disney magic with Cantonese flair―seven themed lands, seasonal parades, and family-friendly rides on Lantau Island.
The ornate stone fa?ade of a 17th-century Jesuit church stands as Macau’s most photographed World Heritage landmark.
Wave-pattern cobblestones, pastel baroque buildings, and lively festivals embody Macau’s Portuguese colonial heart.
Skywalks and the world’s highest commercial bungee jump (233 m) crown this soaring observation tower.
Quiet lanes of sino-Portuguese cottages, seafront temples, and Lord Stow’s original egg-tart bakery evoke old-Macau charm.
Dating to 1488, this sea-goddess temple of incense coils and granite boulders lent Macau its very name: ‘A-Ma-Gao’.
